We're reminded this evening about life and death. The Bible is full of instruction regarding our lives, the analogies of a shadow of a vapor. God, I pray this evening that each and every one of us would be able to say with confidence as Paul did, I know I'm going to go to heaven when I die. I no longer fear death for I've been saved, I've been reconciled. God, I pray that you'd help each and every one of us this evening, myself included, to have a burden, a passion to reach lost people. That we'd take seriously the ministry of reconciliation that's been committed to us. God, we'd be faithful servants, faithful ambassadors to tell a lost and dying world the glorious message of the gospel. In these few moments of invitation, I pray that you'd move and work in our hearts as only you can. I pray that decisions would be made that would please thee. I pray, God, that you'd help us to have an impact on eternity. Well, thank you for all that you'll do. For it's in Christ's name we pray.

segments.text: chapter number 35 this evening. Genesis chapter number 35, we'll be looking at verses 16-29
this evening as we finish up this 35th chapter here in the book of Genesis. As we conclude
this chapter, we're provided with a number of records. I'll read the text of Scripture
and then we'll deal with those and look at this passage maybe from a little peculiar
type of a perspective this evening. But notice with me, last week as we read the first half
and studied through the first 15 verses of the book of, of the 35th chapter of the book
of Genesis, we dealt with the fact that they were returning to Bethel. And what a wonderful
truth that God gave us in that portion of Scripture. And we talked about the fact that
Jacob of course had been to Bethel before and now this was a return for him. And they
were going there for the purpose of worship. And our God is worthy of worship. And we talked
about the importance of preparing for worship and looked at that passage and what a blessing
it was. And now the Bible tells us beginning in verse number 16 that they journeyed from
Bethel. And so they were there, they worshiped, and now they're departing. And the Bible says
this, and there was but a little way to come to Ephrath. And Rachel travailed and she had
hard labor. And it came to pass when she was in hard labor that the midwife said unto her,
fear not, thou shalt have this son also. And it came to pass as her soul was in departing
for she died, that she called his name Benoni, but his father called him Benjamin. And Rachel
died and was buried in the way of Ephrath which is Bethlehem. And Jacob set a pillar
upon her grave, that is the pillar of Rachel's grave unto this day. And Israel journeyed
and spread his tent beyond the tower of Edar. And it came to pass when Israel dwelt in the
land that Reuben went and lay with Bilhah, his father's concubine. And Israel heard it.
The sons of Jacob were twelve, the sons of Leah, Reuben, Jacob's firstborn, and Simeon,
and Levi, and Judah, and Issachar, and Zebulun, the sons of Rachel, Joseph, and Benjamin,
the sons of Bilhah, Rachel's handmaid, Dan, and Naphtali, the sons of Zilpah, Leah's handmaid,
Gad, and Asher. These are the sons of Jacob which were born to him in Paddan Aram. And
Jacob came unto Isaac, his father, unto Mamre, unto the city of Arba, which is Hebron, where
Abraham and Isaac sojourned. The days of Isaac were 104 score years, 180 years old. Wow.
Verse 29, And Isaac gave up the ghost, and died, and was gathered unto his people, being
old and full of days. And his sons Esau and Jacob buried him. Of course you'll remember
that after Jacob received the vision from the Lord to depart from Paddan Aram and return,
we read of the reunion between Jacob and Esau. And now we see this reference for after that
great reunion and we read of all of those things that transpired. There was obviously
a departure and they were in their different separate places. But as you end the 35th chapter
and you see once again a reference to Jacob and Esau, they are together and they are burying
their father Isaac. But as we look at this portion of Scripture in these verses that
are before us this evening, we really see the record of four events that are provided
for us. Number one, we see the record of the birth of Benjamin. And we see that in verses
16 through 18. We have the record of Jacob's sons in verses 23 through 26. That was a question
from the teens on the teen takeover, name the sons of Jacob, right? And if you, there's
a couple of places you can go and you can see the list. And here we find that in just
a few verses of Scripture, God gives us the names of the sons of Jacob. We find that the
text of Scripture before us records for us the death of Rachel. And we read that in verses
18 and in verse number 19. And then we find that the Bible in this portion of Scripture
reveals to us the death of Isaac in verses 27 through 29. And so we read of the birth
of Benjamin, all of the names of Jacob's sons, the death of Rachel and the death of Isaac.
And thus I have titled the message this evening, Life and Death. Life and Death. You think
about all the sons of Jacob that are mentioned in verses 23 through 26. You can go to previous
portions of Scripture and you can read of the record of their birth. And here does not
record for us their birth specifically, only Benjamin's birth is recorded here in this
portion of Scripture. But you are referencing and understanding that each of these sons
of Jacob were born and you can read of that. It's interesting that in these few verses
of Scripture, we read of life and we read of death. Let me begin to think about life
and begin to think about that thought from this portion of Scripture this evening. In
2022 globally, so not just the United States but globally, in 2022 there were about 67

67 million died. So every single second, the exact math based on those estimate numbers
is that there are 4.4 births every second. Globally. 4.4 people are born, so we'd say
4 people, right, because we're not having a partial, right, but you understand the math
exactly. But every second, 4 people are born and 2.1 people, so we'd say 2 people, die.

we don't like talking about death. In fact, there's a big word, a phobia of dying, the
fear of dying, an anxiety of dying, and you talk to some people and they have a fear of
dying. The uncertainty. The fear. In fact, the book of Hebrews talks about, in Hebrews
chapter number 2, you don't need to turn there, but in Hebrews chapter number 2 the Bible
talks about these that had this fear of death and perhaps at one point in your life you
would say, I had a fear of dying. The uncertainty. But we find that the Bible says in Hebrews
2 and verse 14, for as much then as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, he also

the power of death, that is the devil, and it continues and says this in verse 15, and
deliver them who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage. I hope
this evening that you can say, I do not fear death. In saying that you do not fear death,
that does not necessarily mean that you have a death sentence, but it means that you don't
